rubric.prompt:
Given the state of the world today, what do you think should be done to combat poverty?
Read for conciseness, clarity of thought, and form.

option.name: Neal Stephenson (late)
option.explanation: In "Cryptonomicon", Stephenson spent multiple pages talking about breakfast cereal. While hilarious, in recent years his work has been anything but 'concise'.

option.name: HP Lovecraft
option.explanation: If the author wrote something cyclopean that staggers the mind, score it thus.

option.name: Robert Heinlein
option.explanation: Tight prose that conveys a wealth of information about the world in relatively few words. Example, "The door irised open and he stepped inside."

option.name: Neal Stephenson (early)
option.explanation: When Stephenson still had an editor, his prose was dense, with anecdotes about nitrox abuse implying main characters' whole life stories.

option.name: Earnest Hemingway
option.explanation: Score the work this way if it makes you weep, and the removal of a single word would make you sneer.

option.name: Spock
option.explanation: Coolly rational, with a firm grasp of the main topics, a crystal-clear train of thought, and unemotional examination of the facts. This is the only item explained in this category, to show that explained and unexplained items can be mixed.

criterion.name: form
criterion.prompt: Lastly, how is its form? Punctuation, grammar, and spelling all count.

criterion.name: Feedback only
criterion.prompt: This criterion has only written feedback, no options
